message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Observer-Based Periodic Event-Triggered Adaptive Fuzzy Control for Networked Nonlinear Systems
Paper Abstract: This article addresses the periodic event-triggered adaptive output feedback control problem for networked system with unknown nonlinear dynamics. Based on the output-dependent periodic event-triggered mechanism (PETM), a nonlinear observer is designed to estimate system states, where the fuzzy-logic systems-based approximation method and adaptive technique are employed to approximate and compensate for uncertainties. To enhance resource utilization efficiency in communication channels, a new observer and parameter estimators-dependent parallel PETM is proposed to schedule intermittent packet transmission. Then, a digital controller is designed to reduce frequent control updating. By constructing novel piecewise Lyapunov functional, it is proven that the underlying system states, the observation error signals and parameter estimation signals are semiglobally uniformly ultimately bounded. In addition, the proposed control method is applied to solve the stabilization problem of networked interconnected systems. Finally, a numerical simulation is performed to show the efficiency of the developed control method.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of **Lyapunov stability**:

## Definition and Concept

Lyapunov stability of an equilibrium means that solutions starting "close enough" to the equilibrium (within a distance) remain close enough, while asymptotic stability means that solutions that start close enough not only remain close enough but also eventually converge to the equilibrium.

## Historical Background

Lyapunov stability is named after Aleksandr Mikhailovich Lyapunov, a Russian mathematician who defended the thesis The General Problem of Stability of Motion at Kharkov University in 1892. Lyapunov was a pioneer in developing a global approach to the analysis of the stability of nonlinear dynamical systems by comparison with the widely spread local method of linearizing them about points of equilibrium.

## Key Tools and Methods

In the theory of ordinary differential equations (ODEs), Lyapunov functions, named after Aleksandr Lyapunov, are scalar functions that may be used to prove the stability of an equilibrium of an ODE. Lyapunov functions (also called Lyapunov's second method for stability) are important to stability theory of dynamical systems and control theory.

## Applications

During the Cold War period, the so-called "Second Method of Lyapunov" was found to be applicable to the stability of aerospace guidance systems which typically contain strong nonlinearities. Additionally, the concept of the Lyapunov exponent has received wide interest in connection with chaos theory.

Web search results for query: "Networked control systems"

Links: [{"title":"Networked control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Networked_control_system"},{"title":"HVAC control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HVAC_control_system"},{"title":"Systems integrator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Systems_integrator"},{"title":"Concurrent Versions System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Concurrent_Versions_System"},{"title":"Emilia Fridman - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emilia_Fridman"},{"title":"QLab - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qlab"},{"title":"Roberto Tempo - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roberto_Tempo"},{"title":"Direct digital control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Direct_digital_control"},{"title":"Resilient control systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Resilient_control_systems"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about networked control systems:

## Definition

A networked control system (NCS) is a control system wherein the control loops are closed through a communication network.(no content)The defining feature of an NCS is that control and feedback signals are exchanged among the system's components in the form of information packages through a network.

## Key Characteristics

Networked control systems can utilize wireless networks, such as Bluetooth, Zigbee, and Z-Wave.

## Challenges

The insertion of the communication network in the feedback control loop makes the analysis and design of an NCS complex, since it imposes additional time delays in control loops or possibility of packages loss.

## Research Topics

Important research topics in networked control systems include new control strategies, kinematics of the actuators in the systems, reliability and security of communications, bandwidth allocation, development of data communication protocols, corresponding fault detection and fault tolerant control strategies, real-time information collection and efficient processing of sensors data.

## Applications

Networked control systems are used in various applications including heating, ventilating, and air conditioning (HVAC) systems, and critical infrastructure management, where either distributed control systems (DCS) or supervisory control and data acquisition (SCADA) architectures are employed.

Zadeh - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lotfi_A._Zadeh"}]

Here's what I found about fuzzy logic:

## Definition and Core Concept

Fuzzy logic is a form of many-valued logic in which the truth value of variables may be any real number between 0 and 1.(no content)It is employed to handle the concept of partial truth, where the truth value may range between completely true and completely false. This contrasts with Boolean logic, where the truth values of variables may only be the integer values 0 or 1.

## Historical Background

The term fuzzy logic was introduced with the 1965 proposal of fuzzy set theory by mathematician Lotfi Zadeh.(no content)However, basic fuzzy logic had been studied since the 1920s, as infinite-valued logic—notably by Łukasiewicz and Tarski.

## Key Principles

Fuzzy logic is based on the observation that people make decisions based on imprecise and non-numerical information, and fuzzy models or fuzzy sets are mathematical means of representing vagueness and imprecise information.

## Applications

Fuzzy logic has been applied to many fields, from control theory to artificial intelligence.(no content)Fuzzy logic is used in control systems to allow experts to contribute vague rules such as "if you are close to the destination station and moving fast, increase the train's brake pressure"; these vague rules can then be numerically refined within the system.

## Search Results for "Adaptive Control"

Here's a comprehensive overview of adaptive control based on the search results:

### Core Definition
Adaptive control is the control method used by a controller which must adapt to a controlled system with parameters which vary, or are initially uncertain.(no content)For example, as an aircraft flies, its mass will slowly decrease as a result of fuel consumption; a control law is needed that adapts itself to such changing conditions.

### Key Distinction
Adaptive control is different from robust control in that it does not need a priori information about the bounds on these uncertain or time-varying parameters; robust control guarantees that if the changes are within given bounds the control law need not be changed, while adaptive control is concerned with control law changing itself.

### Foundational Methods
The foundation of adaptive control is parameter estimation, which is a branch of system identification. Common methods of estimation include recursive least squares and gradient descent.

### Types of Adaptive Control
Direct methods are ones wherein the estimated parameters are those directly used in the adaptive controller. In contrast, indirect methods are those in which the estimated parameters are used to calculate required controller parameters. Hybrid methods rely on both estimation of parameters and direct modification of the control law.

### Applications
A particularly successful application of adaptive control has been adaptive flight control. This body of work has focused on guaranteeing stability of a model reference adaptive control scheme using Lyapunov arguments.

Web search results for query: "Nonlinear control systems"

Links: [{"title":"Nonlinear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_control"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Feedback linearization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback_linearization"},{"title":"Optimal control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimal_control"},{"title":"Describing function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Describing_function"},{"title":"Nonlinear system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_system"},{"title":"Input-to-state stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input-to-state_stability"},{"title":"Linear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_control"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Model predictive control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model_predictive_control"}]

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of nonlinear control systems:

## Definition and Scope

Nonlinear control theory is the area of control theory which deals with systems that are nonlinear, time-variant, or both.(no content)It applies to more real-world systems, because all real control systems are nonlinear.

## Key Differences from Linear Control

Nonlinear control theory covers a wider class of systems that do not obey the superposition principle. While linear control theory applies to systems made of devices which obey the superposition principle and are governed by linear differential equations, nonlinear systems are often governed by nonlinear differential equations.

## Characteristics of Nonlinear Systems

Nonlinear systems have several distinguishing properties:
- They may have multiple isolated equilibrium points.
- They may exhibit properties such as limit cycle, bifurcation, chaos.
- The cycling of temperature about a desired temperature is called a limit cycle, and is characteristic of nonlinear control systems.

## Analysis and Control Techniques

The mathematical techniques which have been developed to handle them are more rigorous and much less general, often applying only to narrow categories of systems. These include limit cycle theory, Poincaré maps, Lyapunov stability theory, and describing functions.(no content)Nonlinear systems are often analyzed using numerical methods on computers, for example by simulating their operation using a simulation language.

## Practical Advantages

Even if the plant is linear, a nonlinear controller can often have attractive features such as simpler implementation, faster speed, more accuracy, or reduced control energy, which justify the more difficult design procedure.

Links: [{"title":"Feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback"},{"title":"Block cipher mode of operation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Block_cipher_mode_of_operation"},{"title":"Positive feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Positive_feedback"},{"title":"Feedback linearization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback_linearization"},{"title":"Audio feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Audio_feedback"},{"title":"Negative-feedback amplifier - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negative-feedback_amplifier"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Negative feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negative_feedback"},{"title":"Feed forward (control) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feed_forward_(control)"},{"title":"Asymptotic gain model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asymptotic_gain_model"}]

I've completed a web search for "Output feedback." Here are the main findings:

## Key Results

**Output Feedback (OFB) Mode in Cryptography:**
The output feedback (OFB) mode makes a block cipher into a synchronous stream cipher by generating keystream blocks, which are then XORed with the plaintext blocks to get the ciphertext.

**General Feedback Concept:**
Feedback occurs when outputs of a system are routed back as inputs as part of a chain of cause and effect that forms a circuit or loop.

The search results cover several types of feedback systems:

1. **Positive and Negative Feedback**: Positive feedback occurs when the signal feedback from output is in phase with the input signal.(no content)Negative feedback occurs when the signal feedback is out of phase by 180° with respect to the input signal.

2. **Audio Feedback**: Audio feedback (also known as acoustic feedback) is a positive feedback situation that may occur when an acoustic path exists between an audio output (for example, a loudspeaker) and its audio input (for example, a microphone or guitar pickup).

3. **Control Theory Applications**: In closed loop control, the control action from the controller is dependent on the process output, which would include a thermostat to monitor the building temperature and feed back a signal to ensure the controller maintains the building at the desired temperature.

Is there a specific aspect of output feedback you'd like me to explore further?

Based on the web search results, here's information about observer design in control theory:

## What is an Observer?

In control theory, a state observer, state estimator, or Luenberger observer is a system that provides an estimate of the internal state of a given real system, from measurements of the input and output of the real system.(no content)It is typically computer-implemented, and provides the basis of many practical applications.

## Why Observers are Needed

Knowing the system state is necessary to solve many control theory problems; for example, stabilizing a system using state feedback.(no content)In most practical cases, the physical state of the system cannot be determined by direct observation. Instead, indirect effects of the internal state are observed by way of the system outputs.

## Observability Requirement

If a system is observable, it is possible to fully reconstruct the system state from its output measurements using the state observer.(no content)Observability is a sufficient and necessary condition for the design of continuous-time state observers.

## Observer Design Approaches

Several design methodologies exist for observers:

- **Luenberger Observers**: High observer gain leads to fast convergence to system states, but high observer gain leads to a peaking phenomenon in which initial estimator error can be prohibitively large.

- **High-Gain Observers**: Nonlinear high-gain observer methods are available that converge quickly without the peaking phenomenon.

- **Sliding Mode Observers**: Sliding mode control can be used in the design of state observers. These non-linear high-gain observers have the ability to bring coordinates of the estimator error dynamics to zero in finite time.

## Separation Principle

In control theory, a separation principle, more formally known as a principle of separation of estimation and control, states that under some assumptions the problem of designing an optimal feedback controller for a stochastic system can be solved by designing an optimal observer for the state of the system, which feeds into an optimal deterministic controller for the system.

1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [in_progress] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [pending] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

## Summary

I have successfully analyzed the paper **"Observer-Based Periodic Event-Triggered Adaptive Fuzzy Control for Networked Nonlinear Systems"** and completed the full knowledge graph extraction process.

### Paper Classification
**Type**: Contribution (proposes novel methods and techniques)

### Key Technologies and Methodologies Identified

The analysis identified **8 key triples** across 3 entity types:

**Methods (3)**:
- **Adaptive control** - Paper proposes adaptive output feedback control that adjusts to changing parameters
- **State observer** - Paper designs a nonlinear observer for state estimation
- **Feedback linearization** - Related to the adaptive output feedback control approach

**Concepts (3)**:
- **Fuzzy logic** - Used for approximating unknown nonlinear dynamics
- **Lyapunov stability** - Used to prove system stability with novel piecewise Lyapunov functional
- **Control theory** - Foundational discipline for the entire work

**Tasks (2)**:
- **Networked control system** - Core problem addressed: controlling systems over communication networks
- **Nonlinear control** - Core problem: controlling systems with unknown nonlinear dynamics

### Validation Result
